SETS.LaTeX: \text{Let } I \text{ be the set of warehouses (NY, LA, CH, ATL)}; \text{ let } R \text{ be the set of regions (1, 2, 3)}

VARIABLES.name: y_NY
VARIABLES.description: Binary variable indicating whether New York warehouse is opened

VARIABLES.name: y_LA
VARIABLES.description: Binary variable indicating whether Los Angeles warehouse is opened

VARIABLES.name: y_CH
VARIABLES.description: Binary variable indicating whether Chicago warehouse is opened

VARIABLES.name: y_ATL
VARIABLES.description: Binary variable indicating whether Atlanta warehouse is opened

VARIABLES.name: x_NY_1
VARIABLES.description: Quantity shipped from New York to Region 1

VARIABLES.name: x_NY_2
VARIABLES.description: Quantity shipped from New York to Region 2

VARIABLES.name: x_NY_3
VARIABLES.description: Quantity shipped from New York to Region 3

VARIABLES.name: x_LA_1
VARIABLES.description: Quantity shipped from Los Angeles to Region 1

VARIABLES.name: x_LA_2
VARIABLES.description: Quantity shipped from Los Angeles to Region 2

VARIABLES.name: x_LA_3
VARIABLES.description: Quantity shipped from Los Angeles to Region 3

VARIABLES.name: x_CH_1
VARIABLES.description: Quantity shipped from Chicago to Region 1

VARIABLES.name: x_CH_2
VARIABLES.description: Quantity shipped from Chicago to Region 2

VARIABLES.name: x_CH_3
VARIABLES.description: Quantity shipped from Chicago to Region 3

VARIABLES.name: x_ATL_1
VARIABLES.description: Quantity shipped from Atlanta to Region 1

VARIABLES.name: x_ATL_2
VARIABLES.description: Quantity shipped from Atlanta to Region 2
